title: How to Cook Saganaki

steps.headline: Choose a traditional Greek cheese to get the right consistency.
steps.description: For best results, use a Greek cheese such as kasseri, kefalotyri, kefalograviera, halloumi, graviera, or sheep’s milk feta. You want a cheese that is firm and can hold up to high heat. If you use other types of cheese, it may not melt or brown correctly.

steps.headline: Slice the cheese between ⁄4–⁄2 in (0.64–1.27 cm) thick.
steps.description: Use a sharp, medium-sized knife to cut your cheese into slices if it’s in a large chunk. For best results, aim to cut your cheese around ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) thick. This way, the cheese stays in its shape as it melts.

steps.headline: Brush each side lightly with water.
steps.description: Dip a small cooking brush into a cup of water, and brush it over each side of the cheese. If you don’t have a brush, do this with clean hands instead. You want the cheese to be slightly damp so the flour stays on as you fry it. You only need a little bit of water. Just a light sprinkle is enough for the flour to stick.

steps.headline: Cover both sides of the cheese with flour.
steps.description: Pour about 1/4 cup (59 g) of flour onto a plate. Then, dip 1 side of the cheese into the flour after you get it slightly wet. Flip the flour over to cover the other side. The flour helps the outside of the cheese crispen up as it cooks.

steps.headline: Warm up 1 tbsp (15 g) of olive oil in a cast iron pan.
steps.description: For best results, use a cast iron pan, especially if you're adding brandy. The cast iron pan sears the cheese consistently. Add the oil to the pan, and adjust your burner to medium-high heat. You want the pan to be warm before you add the cheese. If you don’t have a cast iron pan, use a nonstick pan instead.

steps.headline: Cook the cheese in the pan on 1 side for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Once the oil starts to separate, the pan is warm enough. Place your slice of cheese in the middle of the pan. Let the cheese cook until it starts to ooze and form a brown crust. If you’re using a nonstick pan, the cooking time may take slightly longer.

steps.headline: Flip the cheese over quickly without hesitation.
steps.description: After the bottom starts to crispen, use a spatula to swap sides. Do this quickly in 1 consistent motion to avoid burning the cheese. If you wiggle the spatula around as you do this, you may mess up your crispy brown crust. This could cause the cheese to ooze out of the bottom rather than the sides.

steps.headline: Cook the other side for 30 seconds or until the cheese is golden brown.
steps.description: After you flip the cheese, the dish is nearly done. Wait about 30 seconds or so for the other side to crispen up. Then, remove the pan from heat when both sides have a rich golden brown color.

steps.headline: Light brandy on fire for an exciting presentation.
steps.description: Remove the pan from the heat and place it on a serving plate. Quickly pour 2 tbsp (30 mL) of brandy into the cast iron pan and light the dish with a match or lighter. As you see the flame, say “Opa!” along with everyone else. Watch the fire for a few seconds to enjoy the display. Then, squeeze 1/2 of a fresh lemon to dull the flame, and garnish the dish with with parsley before eating the Saganaki. This is a popular option for Valentine’s day dinners, date nights, and special occasions. With this dish, the cheese is served out of the cast iron pan. Eat the cheese with slices of pita or bread.

steps.headline: Serve Saganaki with a lemon wedge for a tasty appetizer.
steps.description: For a simple, quick snack, forego the brandy and scoop the cheese with your spatula. Put the Saganaki on a plate, and garnish the dish with 1-3 lemon wedges. Cut into the cheese with a fork and dig in.

steps.headline: Garnish with lime, coriander, and chilis for a flavorful dish.
steps.description: If you want a slightly spicy addition to your savory snack, squeeze 1/2 of a lime over the cheese, add in 1 chopped chilli pepper, and sprinkle 1 tbsp (15 g) of freshly chopped coriander. Serve this with pita bread, or dig in with a fork. This is a great idea if you want to spruce up a traditional dish.

steps.headline: Pour a mix of fig, balsamic, and honey on the cheese for a sweet touch.
steps.description: Before you melt the cheese, combine 8 halved figs, 2 tbsp (30 mL) of balsamic vinegar, 2 tbsp (30 mL) of honey, and 1/4 cup of water in a saucepan. Cook the ingredients over medium-high heat for 10-15 minutes so it thickens up. Let the syrup cool down, and pour it over the cheese immediately after it cooks. Eat this with a fork for a sweet yet savory dish. The balsamic vinegar keeps the taste balance so it doesn’t get too sweet from the fig and honey.
